title: How to get a Japanese name - Quora

response.answer_text: It depends, of cause but I can show five examples to get some ideas. For example, Marcus Túlio Lyuji Murzani Tanaka has registered his name when he got Japanese citizenship as 田中マルクス闘莉王. Marukusu is in katakana and Tulio is in Kanji which can be read like “TOURIOU”. 闘 means to fight and 王 means a king. Since he was a succor player, a fighting king sounds very suitable for him. Tanaka was his original family name because he is half Japanese and half Italian born in Brazil. Martti Turunen was born in Finland and got Japanese passport in 1979 and became a member of the House of Councillors in 2002. His Japanese name, which was used in election was 弦念 丸呈 (Tsurunen Marutei) as he registered. So it seems he chose to keep his original family name to register. Jesse James Wailani Kuhaulua was born in Hawai’i and became a sumo wrestler. His sumo name (shikona) was Takamiyama Daigorou but registered name is 渡辺大五郎 (Daigorou Watanabe). Watanabe was a family name of his wife. He was also popular in TV commercials and variety programs because of his character. His nickname was Jessy. Agnes Meiling Chan was born in Hong Kong and her Chinese name was 陳 美齢 (Chan Meiling). Her husband, Mr. Kaneko is Japanese and her registered Japanese name is 金子 陳 美齢 (Chan Meirin Kaneko). She preserved original sounds as long as possible. She was a famous singer in Japan. Some Korean people may use Japanese name. It is called 通名 (Tsumei) to avoid discrimination. Foe example a famous political scientist Kang Sang-jung’s Japanese name was 永野 鉄男 (Tetsuo Nagano). He was born in Kumamoto Japan and his parents are from Korea which was ruled by Japan at the moment. Now he publishing his books with his Korean name to show his identity. Some “conversion error” occurs because we don’t have L and it would be converted to R. Also every syllable ends with a vowel except N. So John Smith would be JON SUMISU. In addition, how to read Kanji is different between China Mainland (Mandarin), Hong Kong (Cantonese), Korean and Japanese. Some simply convert to Kanji or Katakana but some is named Japanese name. I think Jessy chose traditional name because Sumo is considered a traditional sports but it is kind of exceptional.

As others have said, you don’t usually take a Japanese name unless you get naturalised, i.e., become a full Japanese citizen. Hidezumi Inoue’s answer gives some good examples of how people adopt “Japanese” names on assuming Japanese nationality. (Incidentally, if you become a Japanese citizen you have to give up your original nationality, as Japan doesn’t recognise dual or multiple nationality, but for some countries, such as Australia, your original nationality remains your birthright and you can reclaim it again on returning permanently to your country. Check with your country’s immigration department.) The usual thing for foreigners to do, as others have also said, is to convert your name to katakana. Ask a Japanese friend to help you, then get some other Japanese friends to check it, because there are sometimes multiple ways to transcribe the same foreign name. Another less common method is ateji - using Chinese characters to represent the sounds of your name. Again, ask a trusted friend to help you and get second and third opinions. Since I was learning kendo, I was given the ateji 武錬男 “martial arts - refining - man”, although I used the katakana ブレンダン in everyday life. If you are going to live in Japan for any length of time beyond the tourist visa, you should pick one version of the katakana or ateji and stick to it. Although not many people do, you are actually supposed to register your “official” katakana or ateji name (and your signature). I found this out when I went to register a hanko (a personal seal usually used by Japanese people instead of a signature). Enquire at your local ward, town or city office.
